Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The impact of an empty forest on tree recruitment and community structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fruit-eating vertebrates have experienced steep declines in abundance and diversity in many of the tropical forests in Asia, Africa, and South America. Many of the tropical trees that need high light to grow from seeds to adults depend largely on these vertebrates to carry their seeds to new openings, or gaps, in the forest created by treefalls. This project will investigate whether the disappearance of fruit-eating vertebrates is reducing the abundance of these trees and causing forest gaps to persist and accumulate. To test this, researchers will compare forests on the island of Guam, which has lost nearly all its fruit-eating vertebrates due to the introduction of a predatory snake, and on three nearby islands that retain native, fruit-eating, forest birds and, in one case, a native, fruit-eating bat. Studies will measure the dynamics of forest gaps on the islands, compare the light requirements of 16 common tree species, and test the effects of experimentally preventing dispersal of seeds on islands that do have birds.

This research will directly aid state and federal agencies to manage and restore tropical forests on Guam. Results should also be of use to managers of other tropical forests, since many pioneer species in the tropics are dispersed by vertebrates, and enlarge our understanding of the potential environmental consequences of introducing species to new areas. The project will provide scientific training for Pacific Islanders and run a special, three-week course in island ecology for students from local colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vertebrates that eat fruit can be important for increasing germination through gut passage, moving seeds to areas with a higher probability of survival, and enabling plants to colonize new areas. We hypothesized that vertebrate seed dispersers may also affect forest structure and species diversity by enabling seeds of quick-growing pioneer species to colonize newly created treefall gaps.

To test this, we took advantage of an accidental experiment in the Mariana Islands, where all native frugivores have been lost from the island of Guam due to the invasive brown treesnake, while the nearby islands of Saipan and Rota have retained relatively heathy frugivore communities. We created 44 experimental treefall gaps across the three islands and monitored regeneration in the gaps for the next 4 years. In a portion of the gaps, we added seeds to simulate the presence of dispersers, or removed seedlings that were the result of dispersal to simulate the absence of dispersers.

We found that gaps with vertebrate seed dispersal have a more diverse seed bank and seedling community, and that the gaps close more quickly than those without vertebrate dispersal (Figure 1). This is largely due to widespread dispersal of pioneer tree species by vertebrates. Over time, based on results from our forest model, loss of dispersers will lead to a more open forest structure. We also demonstrated that dispersal increases alpha diversity and decreases beta diversity, a concept that is well-known theoretically, but has yet to be demonstrated in the field. These results demonstrate the importance of maintaining a healthy community of vertebrate frugivores, particularly in tropical forests, where the vast majority of tree species are dispersed by vertebrates.

Over the course of this grant, we trained 9 early career researchers as technicians, and led one 3-week field course on island ecology for 15 participants from Northern Marianas College and University of Guam. Two of our crew members on this grant have since gone on to graduate school. We focused on recruiting and training people from Pacific Islands, and as a result, 7 of our crew members were from the Marianas or nearby islands.

We have shared results with local & regional agencies and stakeholders via social media, presentations at an annual conference on Guam, and in personal meetings. In addition, ISU PI Rogers and colleagues, with support from the University of Guam Western Pacific Tropical Research Center, organized the inaugural Marianas Terrestrial Conservation Conference in 2017, a 2-day conference with 40 presenters and over 200 attendees. Several presentions shared results from this project at the conference. We have disseminated research results broadly by publishing 4 papers to date in high-profile peer-reviewed journals and presenting at national and international meetings.
